Current and forecasted Sacramento River stage at the Fremont Weir. At 32 feet, water will overtop Fremont Weir and enter the Yolo Bypass.

Aerial photo mosaic from the March 1998 flood event, showing visible sediment plumes corresponding to flows from the four major tributaries of the Yolo Bypass. Source: Department of Water Resources, as published in Sommer, Harrell & Swift (2008). Extreme hydrologic banding in a large-river Floodplain, California, U.S.A. Hydrobiologia 598(1):409-415. doi:10.1007/s10750-007-9159-1
The Sacramento River (right) overtopping the Fremont Weir and spilling into the Yolo Bypass on 30 March 2011 (Paul J Hames / CA DWR)
Sacramento Weir on 30 March 2011. High water levels are seeping through the weir's plank needles but the gates have not yet been fully opened (Paul J Hames / CA DWR)
Cache Creek Setting Basin Weir, where Cache Creek flows into the Yolo Bypass, on 30 March 2011. Note the visible differences in sediment load (Paul J Hames / CA DWR)
